title: 111_hr3923
content: The Act is titled the "Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District Land Exchange Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act, titled the "Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District Land Exchange Act," defines key terms such as District, Federal land, and National Forest, specifically referring to parcels of land in the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forest in Colorado. The "Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District Land Exchange Act" defines terms like National Forest, non-Federal land, and Secretary, related to a proposed land exchange in Colorado. The "Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District Land Exchange Act" defines terms related to a proposed land exchange in Colorado. SEC. 3. LAND EXCHANGE. The Act allows for a land exchange between the District and the Secretary, with the District conveying non-Federal land to the Secretary in exchange for Federal land. The exchange is subject to applicable laws, with the Secretary able to accept a cash payment exceeding 25% of the Federal land's value. The land exchange under subsection (a) allows the Secretary to accept a cash payment exceeding 25% of the Federal land's value. The District must cover costs for surveys, appraisals, and administrative expenses. The exchange is subject to valid existing rights and any additional terms set by the Secretary. The land exchange under subsection (a) must be completed within 1 year of the Act's enactment. If not completed, the Secretary can offer to sell the Federal land to the District at fair market value. The Secretary may offer to sell the Federal land to the District at fair market value. Proceeds from the sale will be deposited in a fund for land acquisition in the National Forest. Proceeds from the sale of Federal land may be used by the Secretary for acquiring land in the National Forest. The acquired non-Federal land will be added to the National Forest and managed according to specific laws and regulations. Any public order withdrawing Federal land from use can be revoked. Revocation of public orders withdrawing Federal land is allowed to convey the land to the District. The Federal land is withdrawn from entry and appropriation until conveyed to the District. The House of Representatives passed the document on July 13, 2010, attested by Lorraine C. Miller, Clerk.
